citations.narrative:
Seventeen dogs over 4 months of age have not been added to the facility’s Record of Dogs on Hand (APHIS form 7005).
They are still being inventoried by their puppy cage cards. Cage cards are an acceptable form of inventory for dogs under
4 months of age. Accurate acquisition information is necessary for APHIS officials to make positive identification of
animals during inspection and to properly trace their movements. The licensee shall make, keep, and maintain an
approved method of documentation which fully and correctly disclose all information concerning each dog purchased or
otherwise acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported,
euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer. The records shall include any offspring born of any animal while
in his or her possession or under his or her control. The licensee must record the acquisition information on an approved
document (APHIS form 7005) for all dogs and ensure all required acquisition information is properly and accurately
documented at all times.

The licensee is missing the annual distemper and parvovirus vaccine dates as well as their deworming (ivermec) dates for
female Bichon "Randi". The licensee states vaccines and deworming are done when being groomed 2-3 times per year.
When this dog was groomed on January 15, 2024, the vaccine and deworming date weren't updated as done. The last
recorded date for distemper and parvovirus vaccines and ivermec deworming was March 2, 2023. The lack of medical
records makes it difficult to determine if the animals are receiving vaccinations and deworming. This information is needed
for APHIS inspectors to ensure the medical care is being provided by the facility.
The licensee must maintain complete and maintain updated medical records including the identity of the animal, including
identifying marks, tattoos, or tags on the animal and the animal’s breed, sex, and age; Provided, however, that routine
husbandry, such as vaccinations, preventive medical procedures, or treatments, performed on all animals in a group (or
herd), may be kept on a single record.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives and the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Jennifer Walker, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.75(a)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
Seventeen dogs over 4 months of age have not been added to the facility’s Record of Dogs on Hand (APHIS form 7005). 
They are still being inventoried by their puppy cage cards. Cage cards are an acceptable form of inventory for dogs under 
4 months of age. Accurate acquisition information is necessary for APHIS officials to make positive identification of 
animals during inspection and to properly trace their movements. The licensee shall make, keep, and maintain an 
approved method of documentation which fully and correctly disclose all information concerning each dog purchased or 
otherwise acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, 
euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer. The records shall include any offspring born of any animal while 
in his or her possession or under his or her control. The licensee must record the acquisition information on an approved 
document (APHIS form 7005) for all dogs and ensure all required acquisition information is properly and accurately 
documented at all times. 
3.13(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee is missing the annual distemper and parvovirus vaccine dates as well as their deworming (ivermec) dates for 
female Bichon "Randi". The licensee states vaccines and deworming are done when being groomed 2-3 times per year. 
When this dog was groomed on January 15, 2024, the vaccine and deworming date weren't updated as done. The last 
recorded date for distemper and parvovirus vaccines and ivermec deworming was March 2, 2023. The lack of medical 
records makes it difficult to determine if the animals are receiving vaccinations and deworming. This information is needed 
for APHIS inspectors to ensure the medical care is being provided by the facility. 
The licensee must maintain complete and maintain updated medical records including the identity of the animal, including 
identifying marks, tattoos, or tags on the animal and the animal’s breed, sex, and age; Provided, however, that routine 
husbandry, such as vaccinations, preventive medical procedures, or treatments, performed on all animals in a group (or 
herd), may be kept on a single record. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives and the licensee.

Additional Inspectors: 
Jennifer Walker, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
